title: Wednesday, 28th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Welcome

PM11:02am

Quick note on ML transcripts...

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Yes, we've had tech problems -- but the issue is being looked at.

PM11:03am

Should have a fix soon, but for the moment I will have to publish separate posts with the relevant link.

PM11:03am

Bear with us.

11:03 am
undefined
PM11:03am

Who shall we have as our pic of the day?

PM11:03am

Andrew Bailey, perhaps

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:04am

Boss of the FCA

PM11:04am

We've been light on Bailey since he got the job

11:04 am
PM11:04am

I'm not quite sure why.

PM11:04am

Maybe cos we threw so many bricks at his predecessor

PM11:04am

Thought we should give the new guy time to screw up.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Has he, with this latest fund industry tome?

PM11:05am

Dunno

BE11:05am

It's identical to the interim report.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

If it's a screwup, it's one that's been flagged.

PM11:06am

Lunch - and hospitality generally -- was already history for fund managers.

PM11:06am

Flagged screw-up

11:06 am
PM11:06am

That actual final report -- if you want to compare with the interim report -- is here

PM11:06am

https://www.fca.or...udies/ms15-2-3.pdf

BE11:06am

In terms of patches of interest, I'd highlight the launch of an investment platforms market study.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Retail investors do not appear to benefit from economies of scale when pooling their money together through direct–to–consumer platforms.

BE11:07am

Well, duh. Hargreaves' margins tell you that.

PM11:07am

hehehe

11:07 am
Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,304, down 33 (-2.47%), High: 1,325, Low: 1,289, Volume: 1.32m
BE11:07am

Otherwise, the headlines are as expected.

BE11:08am

All-in fee disclosure, standardised cost and charge disclosure.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

We're getting a working group on benchmark and performance reporting ahead of detailed consultation on all three shortly.

PM11:08am

Any thoughts on this threatened/delayed attack on 'investment consultants'

BE11:09am

A stronger duty to act in the best interests of investors? Hm.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

I don't have a lot in the way of thoughts, owing to a lack of interest, but Morgan Stanley can help out,

PM11:10am

Excellent

BE11:10am

The FCA is requiring clearer communication of fund charges, including a single all-in fee, and the impact at the point of sale in ongoing communication to retail investors. We note that there is no explicit requirement for asset managers to bear transaction costs and other charges. The FCA highlights impending changes in MiFID II and PRIIPs which will already require the disclosure of a single all-in fee to investors and intends to consult further on proposals on communication of fees and charges later in the year.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

The FCA is proposing to strengthen the requirements for asset managers to act in the best interests of investors through a combination of (i) clarity of our expectations, (2) introducing independence on governance boards and (3) introducing a prescribed responsibility under the SM&CR. This is also subject to further consultation.

BE11:11am

Proposals to prohibit retention of box profits with any benefit from such profits accruing to the fund as well as requiring asset managers to provide full disclosure of box management in fund prospectus. The FCA plans to carry out additional consultation on these proposals.

BE11:11am

(@Boncoeur: I've no idea. Try personal finance.)

11:11 am
BE11:12am

The study will consider how ‘direct to consumer’ and intermediated investment platforms compete to win new and retain existing customers. The study will also explore whether platforms enable retail investors to access investment products that offer value for money. The FCA is seeking to assess what can be done to improve competition between platforms as well as improve consumer outcomes.

BE11:12am

Stock implications: Jupiter and Aberdeen have the highest proportion of AUM from UK domiciled clients per Exhibit 1. For the European traditional asset management sector as a whole, our base case models 10% average price compression in management fees over the next two to three years (see our recent blue paper: The World Turned Upside Down) . We note that the FCA proposals on fees and making it easier for retail investors to move share classes could accelerate fee pressure.

BE11:13am

And Numis.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Our conclusion is that on the one hand, the industry will likely be
overall relieved that the report does not really say anything new that hadn't already been said in the interim report. On the other hand, the report does not seem truly "final", with the FCA suggesting further consultation on a number of topics is required, with new deadlines in the future (consultant CMA referral decision by Sep-17, other outstanding items by Dec-17). The industry thus faces a further period of regulatory uncertainty. We conclude that the active management industry challenges of revenue margin pressure, weak flows, rising operational costs and further regulation are not going away any time soon. Consequently we continue to expect further sector consolidation

PM11:15am

Thanks for all that

BE11:15am

RBC as well, since we're here.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The FCA’s final findings are contained in a 114 page report. Thus, our views contained herein are preliminary in nature. However, we note that the
final remedy package is relatively in line with the initial findings, and while the tone of the report is negative, it is largely as anticipated with (at first
glance) no significant unexpected negative surprises. Nonetheless, it is our opinion that fee pressure in the asset management sector will continue
to intensify, and the likely impact from the FCA asset management market study will be higher costs (compliance, regulatory and operating) and lower management fees over time; however, neither of these trends should come as a surprise and are already an ongoing feature in the industry. Today’s report has more of an impact on sentiment in our opinion, which is negative as the FCA is keen to increase price transparency and promote all-in pricing to start a price war to the benefit of retail investors. The tone of the report is populist in nature, and the impact is likely to play out over time. In general, asset manager shares prices and valuation multiples have increased so far in 2017, aided by an improvement in net flows, higher levels and favourable FX movements. Given that and the FCA’s stance, our view of the sector remains that – with a couple of exemptions – the sector is largely fairly valued, and the market may be overly complacent with the risks faced by sector participants.

BE11:17am

(@Bonceur, re Hargreaves margins. Try this: https://ftalphavil...17-05-17/?mhq5j=e2 )

BE11:17am

(And this: https://ftalphavil...17-05-18/?mhq5j=e2 )

11:17 am
BE11:17am

(And this: https://ftalphavil...17-05-16/?mhq5j=e2 )

BE11:18am

(It's a subject we've touched on every now and then.)

undefined
11:18 am
PM11:18am

Footsie flat

PM11:19am

Well, down 6 points currently

PM11:19am

It's a real mixed bag this morning

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Yeah, oil and tech.

BE11:19am

We have lots of the former and not much of the latter.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,119, down 6.5 (-0.31%), High: 2,127, Low: 2,100, Volume: 1.49m
11:20 am
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 459.85, down 0.45 (-0.10%), High: 462.15, Low: 454.90, Volume: 4.86m
BE11:21am

.................... Tech's probably the more interesting theme

BE11:21am

Having another rotation out, with Sophos currently leading us down.

11:21 am
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 449.10, down 21.9 (-4.65%), High: 467.00, Low: 447.70, Volume: 1.61m
PM11:21am

Across the board rotation is it?

BE11:22am

Pretty much, looking across Europe. Though Sophos is also in part on a Cenkos downgrade.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Saying that if you want to invest in UK tech it's probably your best option, but the alternative is not to bother.

BE11:23am

Martin O'Sullivan's the analyst here.

BE11:23am

After a heady six months during which Sophos gained 75%, we move from Buy to Hold as the shares are now at our target price of 470p. It was a “best idea” and remains a core tech holding for us. Arguably, Sophos is the best story in UK mid/large cap tech since ARM Holdings. However, after such a run, during which the shares have closed the EV/Sales gap with US peers, the prospect of further outsized returns has significantly diminished in the near term, in our view.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Despite being fairly new to the public markets, Sophos has proved its chops as a very credible operator with a track record of beating/raising estimates. The outlook for FY18 is for mid-to-high teens billings growth, 50-100bps improvement in cash EBITDA and FCF broadly unchanged from the high base achieved in FY17. Sophos has also provided strong mid-term guidance to 2020, which is for billings of c$1.0bn (largely driven by similar renewal rates), uFCF in the range $220-240m, with adjusted EBIT of $100m by 2020 and around a 100‐150 basis point cash EBITDA margin improvement per annum. This is equivalent to billings CAGR of c17%, which was ahead of expectations for mid-teens.

BE11:23am

The recent “WannaCry” attacks, the Parliamentary report in February highlighting need for a “National Cyber Security Strategy” and European GDPR legislation from 2018, all show the newsflow is in the right direction for Sophos. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Sophos is making strong progress on all performance metrics. However, the shares have now broadly closed the valuation gap to US peers which we previously highlighted, and have hugely outperformed the benchmarks. We believe the shares may be range bound in region of 450p-500p in the near term.

BE11:23am

Valuation fair: At 470p (our target), Sophos now trades in-line with the peer group whose average EV/Sales is 3.7x. There is scope for the shares to trade at a premium given Sophos is outperforming its peer group in terms of billings growth and market share gains, but the prospect of a UK tech company trading at a sustainable premium to US peers is a low-percentage bet. That said, the company’s robust fundamentals underpin the valuation. Key catalysts for the shares will be: 1) continued billings growth momentum from networks and enduser products; and 2) margin improvements associated with operating leverage.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Have to say, we (by which I mean I) were wrong about Sophos at IPO. Funny jumble of stuff, somewhat troubled history, odd way of adding up its numbers, PE getting out ......

BE11:25am

.... also the fact that we, corporately, are customers of Sophos and using it each day doesn't fill me with confidence.

PM11:26am

These are not bad reasons to be wary

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Can't argue with the post-IPO gain though.

PM11:26am

But yes, the price all but doubled from the float

BE11:27am

A reminder that Neil Campling is a bull on it. From a week or so ago:

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Sophos see a medium term target of c.$1B in billings, unlevered free cash flow in the range of $220-240M, and around a 100-150 basis point cash EBITDA margin improvement per annum giving adjusted operating profit of $100+ million by FY20. If we take 2020 as a target for the mid-term then guidance suggests there could be a significant $60M-100M increase to unlevered FCF consensus estimates at that time and an increase of c. 20-25% to consensus EBITDA. This guidance should also be remembered in context that it was given before the potential upside from new product demands given the proliferation of cyber-attacks.

BE11:27am

That's Northern Trust.

BE11:35am

Anyway, here's what's happening to forecasts.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Via Jefferies, to begin.

BE11:36am

FY17 PBT at £159m vs cons at £166m. Rail likely to be the focus because they
have taken an £84m exceptional to provide for expected losses on East Coast over the next
2-years. This raises 3 questions: 1) presumably no change in the group’s expectation for
adjusted FY18 EPS benefits from this exceptional. The provision taken this year and released
against future losses - without that, FY18 would be having to absorb these expected losses
on East Coast. 2) How can we be confident the East Coast losses don’t continue in year 3
and onwards? 3) What does the East Coast experience mean for the group’s future appetite/
bidding in UK Rail (shortlisted for EMT, S/Eastern and W.Coast)? Whilst the group talks to
discussions with the DfT around the E.Coast contract, expect the market, at least initially, to
look through the group's steer of its unchanged expectations for adj EPS for the year and
be more concerned around the rail unit.

BE11:36am

And Barclays.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Stagecoach has given more guidance around the East Coast rail franchise, which includes a provision taken related to anticipated losses over the next two years. Discussions around contractual changes are ongoing, and could take up to a year to get through. Once this is completed Stagecoach expects the franchise to be profitable (2-3% margin) from 2019 onwards. In the meanwhile, they are taking a provision of £84mn to reflect the losses anticipated over the next few years. Although 2H rail revenue growth was better than 1H, this trend has reversed again in the last 8 weeks, in part perhaps due to the terror related incidents in the UK. Elsewhere in the business, bus trends continue, London bus is experiencing some wage inflation and North America is showing some tentative signs of improvement. Expectations for FY18 EPS are broadly unchanged, with consensus sitting around 20.5p, but with a wide range around this due to different treatments of East Coast profitability, which should now narrow given the aforementioned provisions and guidance.

BE11:38am

I think I quoted the dollar amount above re the writeoff, incidentally. It's a £84.1m provision.

PM11:38am

ok

11:38 am

PM11:38am

It's just the use of historic tax losses that brings the headline rate down

PM11:38am

11:38 am

BE11:39am

BE11:40am

There's BT.

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 292.75, up 4.25 (+1.47%), High: 292.95, Low: 288.55, Volume: 8.51m
BE11:42am

Macquarie saying enough is enough.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

First time it's ever been a buyer, apparently. Which, given the share price performance, looks a fair position to take.

BE11:42am

In our view consensus is now sufficiently cautious on the future FCF generation and is implying too much negativity from FTTp and missing the upside at EE from BT’s extraordinary spectrum position. We believe the returns outlook has been rebased to deliverable levels

BE11:43am

BT is in an unparalleled position; BT has 280MHz of total spectrum in the UK, more than any other European operator. In our view BT/EE will have the only wholly-owned vertically integrated end-to-end 5G network in the UK. We expect other operators to have limited 5G network scale or combine networks and sell them to a neutral host. In the upcoming 3.4GHz auctions we expect BT to spend £100m for 15MHz paired.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

(Speaking as someone who's typing this via a £20 a month connection wired through 60-year-old copper, I've no idea what I'd do with a vertically integrated end-to-end 5G network.)

BE11:45am

(Honestly. What's it for?)

BE11:45am

We expect BT to announce a comprehensive FTTp build in the next six months following the kick-off of the consultation in July 2017. We expect BT to target over 1m homes pa and a target of 10m in total by 2025 in addition to the g.fast target of 10m. Our budget remains £500m pa and is implied in our capex uplift in FY18/19 from when we expect an additional £200m pa. In our model 2020/21 is the positive turning point in Openreach OCF

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Our FY17/18 and 18/19 EPS are +1% but from FY19/20 we assume a recovery due to the combination of superior wireless proposition and FTTp with over 6% EPS upgrades.
We are increasing our target to 330p from 270p on the strength of EE’s wireless position and the constructive view we have on FTTp in the mid-term. We expect further rationalisation of the UK market as networks evolve to meet the demands of 5G will solidify BT’s competitive position. We have increased our long-term FCF forecasts for EE to reflect the excellent spectrum position and the benefit of a FTTP roll-out which will underpin 5G small cells.

BE11:46am

The dividend has been set at realistic levels, in our view. The change in the company’s dividend policy is such that our estimates are identical to consensus with annual growth of 5% in FY17/18 and 3-4% thereafter. The shares yielded 5.6%

PM11:46am

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 257.20, up 6.5 (+2.59%), High: 260.70, Low: 253.00, Volume: 3.11m
BE11:51am

America's doing that thing again.

PM11:51am

Ah yes, saw that!

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Pretending it's going to legalise sports betting.

BE11:51am

US Supreme Court agrees to hear the case from New Jersey

BE11:51am

To allow sports betting at casinos and racetracks in the New
Jersey.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Was there a damper squib than the Nevada sports betting legislation? The numbers are pathetic.

BE11:52am

Here's Stifel to remind you of the pathetic numbers.

BE11:52am

There is obviously smaller potential in New Jersey than Nevada, where WMH earned an EBIT of £14.3m last year with a 26% market share. One should also note that since online casino gaming was permitted in New Jersey, growth has been below expectations with limited profitability

11:52 am
BE11:53am

So while this is a welcome step in the right direction, it will only be a game-changer if there is further legislative change permitting larger states to legalize online sports betting.

BE11:54am

And Canaccord, once it opens.

BE11:55am

The pace of change in the US laws regarding sports betting and online gaming has been glacial. But there was an interesting milestone yesterday, pointing to the potential legalisation of sports betting across much of the US.
The US Supreme court announced yesterday that it will hear arguments on whether to permit sports betting in New Jersey. If favourable, it would overturn the rather curious Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA). PASPA only permits racetrack betting on "animal racing", other than (as a quirk of history) Nevada, which is allowed fully licensed sports books, and in Oregon, Montana and Delaware, which have sports lotteries. New Jersey's proposals would only allow sports betting at Casinos and Racetracks, and would prohibit betting on some sports (ie College football). But if New Jersey wins, then other States will undoubtedly follow, and we could expect to see land-based sports betting proliferate across much of the US, with some obvious exception (ie Utah).
There is no guarantee that the hearing will be favourable, and realistically, the outcome is unlikely to be clear until 2018. But this does suggest a sea change in attitudes towards sports betting - the NBA, for example, is now favourable to legalising betting on basketball, having previously been fiercely opposed.
The major initial beneficiary of any change would be William Hill (Hold, TP 290p), which is the leading land-based sports betting operator in Nevada. However, we would see the legalisation of some land-based sports betting as paving the way for Online sports betting in some states. We believe the most obvious beneficiaries would be GVC (Buy, TP 850p) and 888 (Buy, TP 330p), which both operate in New Jersey (Casino and Poker), and have strong domestic partnerships - with MGM and Caesars, respectively. Playtech (Buy, TP 1140p) would also be well placed as a potential technology supplier to domestic operators.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

America's relationship with gambling is so weird. There's still this idea that it's somehow fun.

PM11:56am

BE11:57am

12:00 pm

PM12:01pm

BE12:01pm

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Let me grab Citi to sum up where we are.

BE12:02pm

Dixons Carphone has reported results in line with consensus with
Headline PBT of £501m, and dividend slightly ahead of our expectations. The announcement of a further honeybee contract should be well received by the market. Outlook comments suggest that the consumer demand environment for DC is still holding up with further scope for market share gains in electricals. Mobile performance in our view will be more dependent on product launches given the ongoing strength of SIM only in the market. There is little in the statement that should change consensus FY18 PBT expectations at this stage.

BE12:02pm

Implications — April FY18 PBT retained — We forecast FY18 PBT £511m, EPS 32.3p, +4.3% yoy. This assumes Group UK & Ireland LFL sales growth of -0.1% (including +2% contributions from store closures), Northern Europe LFL sales of +1.8% and Southern Europe +6.0%. Our overall EBIT is £529m. Our EPS of 32.3p assumes a tax rate of 25%

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Investment case — The group’s core business should benefit from broader market share gains in mobile, consumer electronics and domestic appliances, in our view. With Capex set to decline by £50m to £200m in FY18e and the exceptional charges relating to the property optimization reducing, we forecast FCF conversion will improve from 17% in FY17e to 35-45% over FY18 and FY19, driving a FCF yield to 6.5% in FY18e from 3% in FY17e.

BE12:04pm

CIti's a buyer, saying they should be at 15x. Though I'm not clear as to why.
